tsq-41267b.6.title: Feature: tsq watch live view for active tasks
tsq-41267b.6.description: Design and implement a live terminal view for open/in_progress tasks with compact hierarchy, blockers, and quick situational awareness.

notes.text:
[UX Plan: tsq watch live view]

Design direction
- Personality: Precision & Density + Utility & Function.
- Visual tone: monochrome-first with semantic status accents only.
- Goal: instant scan of active work (open + in_progress), blockers, and ownership in one stable terminal screen.

Problem and users
- Primary users: coding agents and developers coordinating multiple active tasks.
- Job to be done: answer "what is active now, what is blocked, what changed" without rerunning list commands.
- Success criteria:
  1) first actionable item identifiable in <3 seconds,
  2) blocked items obvious without reading full details,
  3) output remains readable at 80/100/120 column terminals.

Scope and constraints
- Command target: `tsq watch`.
- V1 scope: single repo, single user, local polling (no daemon).
- Default content scope: status in open|in_progress only.
- Non-goal: interactive editing/mutation from watch view in V1.
- Deterministic ordering: same ordering as list path (priority then created_at then id) unless explicitly sorted.

Information architecture (single-screen)
1) Header line: repo/task store + timestamp + refresh interval + active filters.
2) Summary line: total active, in_progress, open, blocked-by-deps count.
3) Main table/tree region: active tasks with compact metadata.
4) Footer hint line: key hints and how to exit.

Data fields per row
- Required: status glyph+label, id, title, priority, assignee.
- Conditional: parent marker, blocker count, dependency hints.
- Optional expansion lane (when width allows): blockers list and dependents list.

State model
- Loading: clear indicator "loading..." in main region.
- Healthy refresh: timestamp updates each cycle.
- No active tasks: explicit empty state "no active tasks".
- Error transient (IO/lock/read): keep last good frame + inline error banner.
- Error persistent: banner escalates severity after N consecutive failures.

Accessibility/legibility
- Never rely on color alone; keep glyph + status text always present.
- No-color fallback must preserve all semantics.
- Keep IDs and status left-anchored for rapid scan.
- Ensure copy/paste stability (plain text, no cursor-control required for fallback mode).

Layout and responsive behavior
- Wide (>=120): single-line primary rows + inline meta flow.
- Medium (90-119): primary row + second meta lane for blockers/dependents.
- Narrow (<90): truncated title, always show status+id; move meta to wrapped lines.

ASCII wireframe
[tsq watch] repo=tasque  refreshed=2026-02-18T01:30:00Z  interval=2s  filter=status:open,in_progress
active=7  in_progress=3  open=4  blocked=2
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
◐ in_progress tsq-41267b.2 Implement: tsq stale command + service query [p1 @SG] {blocks-on: tsq-41267b.2.1}
○ open        tsq-41267b.3.1 Decision: list filter contract [p1]
○ open        tsq-41267b.6   Feature: tsq watch live view for active tasks [p1]
  {unblocks: tsq-41267b.6.1,tsq-41267b.6.2}
...
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
q quit | r refresh-now | p pause/resume | h help

Interaction model (V1)
- Non-interactive mutations; watch is read-only.
- Keys:
  - q: quit,
  - r: force immediate refresh,
  - p: pause/resume polling,
  - h: inline key help.
- If key handling is not available in given terminal/runtime, fallback to pure polling output mode.

Command contract proposal
- `tsq watch`
- `tsq watch --interval <seconds>` (default 2, min 1)
- `tsq watch --status <status>` (repeatable or comma list)
- `tsq watch --assignee <name>`
- `tsq watch --tree` (optional tree mode within watch)
- `tsq watch --once` (single frame render, no loop)
- `tsq watch --json` => newline-delimited frame objects for automation.

JSON frame shape (watch --json)
- `{ schema_version, command:"tsq watch", ok:true, data:{ frame_ts, interval_s, filters, summary, tasks } }`
- summary includes: total, open, in_progress, blocked.

Performance and reliability
- Polling loop should avoid overlapping refreshes (skip if previous cycle still running).
- On errors, emit non-fatal frame with `ok:false` while retaining process unless fatal setup error.
- Use existing read path (`loadProjectedState`) to preserve durability semantics.

Acceptance criteria for implementation task
1) default watch shows only open/in_progress,
2) refresh loop stable for 10+ minutes without memory growth issues,
3) deterministic ordering preserved across frames,
4) clear empty/error states,
5) snapshot tests for 80/100/120-width frame rendering.

tsq-41267b.7.title: Feature: spec durability workflow (attach/check/claim gate)
tsq-41267b.7.description: Prevent loss of detailed implementation/design specs by attaching canonical specs to tasks, validating integrity, and gating implementation workflows.

notes.text:
[Spec durability schema and storage proposal]

Goal
- Make full task specs first-class durable artifacts.
- Ensure specs are discoverable, validated, and referenced from task records.

Schema updates (task model)
- Add optional task-level fields:
  - spec_path?: string            # canonical location under .tasque/specs
  - spec_fingerprint?: string     # sha256 of canonical spec content
  - spec_attached_at?: string     # ISO timestamp
  - spec_attached_by?: string     # actor
  - spec_version?: number         # schema for spec metadata (start at 1)
  - spec_status?: "attached"|"missing"|"drifted"|"invalid"

Event model changes
- Add event types:
  - task.spec_attached
  - task.spec_checked
- task.spec_attached payload:
  - spec_path, spec_fingerprint, spec_attached_at, spec_attached_by, spec_version
- task.spec_checked payload:
  - spec_path, expected_fingerprint, observed_fingerprint, status, checked_at, checker

Projection behavior
- task.spec_attached updates task spec metadata and marks spec_status=attached.
- task.spec_checked updates spec_status to attached|drifted|invalid|missing.
- Keep append-only audit history; never mutate history in-place.

JSON output impact
- show/list/search JSON includes spec_* fields when present.
- `tsq spec check --json` returns:
  - task_id, spec_path, status, expected_fingerprint, observed_fingerprint, missing_sections[]

[Structured storage under .tasque]

Canonical storage layout
- Root: .tasque/specs/
- Per-task directory: .tasque/specs/<task-id>/
- Files:
  - spec.md                 # canonical full spec document
  - metadata.json           # optional generated metadata cache
  - history/<timestamp>.md  # optional retained snapshots (if --keep-history)

Why per-task directory
- Stable discoverability by task ID.
- Easy copy/move/archive with task lifecycle.
- Supports future attachments without path churn.

Attach flow (`tsq spec attach <id> <source>`)
1) Resolve task ID.
2) Read source (file path only in V1).
3) Validate minimum structure headings.
4) Write canonical `.tasque/specs/<id>/spec.md` atomically.
5) Compute sha256 fingerprint on canonical content.
6) Append `task.spec_attached` event with metadata.
7) Return JSON envelope with path + fingerprint.

Check flow (`tsq spec check <id>`)
1) Resolve task and expected metadata.
2) Load canonical spec path.
3) Recompute fingerprint.
4) Validate required sections.
5) Append `task.spec_checked` event.
6) Return status and diagnostics.

Required sections (V1)
- Overview
- Constraints / Non-goals
- Interfaces (CLI/API)
- Data model / schema changes
- Acceptance criteria
- Test plan

[Command surface and policy]

Commands
- tsq spec attach <id> <source-path>
  - --force                # overwrite canonical spec and write new attach event
  - --print-path           # output canonical path only
- tsq spec check <id>
  - --strict               # exit non-zero if missing section or fingerprint drift
- tsq spec show <id>       # print canonical spec path + summary metadata

Claim/start policy
- Extend update claim flow with optional gate:
  - tsq update <id> --claim --require-spec
- Behavior with --require-spec:
  - fail if no spec_path/fingerprint
  - fail if check status is missing/drifted/invalid
  - pass only when current canonical spec hash matches expected fingerprint and sections valid

Exit codes
- 0 success
- 1 validation/user error
- 2 IO/storage error
- 4 spec integrity/policy gate failure (new)

Planning defaults
- Make spec attach/check optional globally in V1, strict per-command via --require-spec.
- Keep schema backward compatible for tasks without spec metadata.
